comments.commentBody:
"No, it isn't typical of most employer plans that you have to pay your deductible in full before insurance kicks in."

I don't know where you work -- but this is exactly the only health insurance choice, at the large corporation I work for. The one and only choice, for my family, is a plan that requires me to pay just under $600 a month with a $4,900 deductible. And, except for routine checkups (allegedly), this $4,900 dollars has to be paid in full, by me, before the health insurance starts finding ways to "legally" weasel out of paying one red cent. (And I say "allegedly" on the "free" checkups because they've never actually paid for any checkup.) And even if they do pay one red cent, it's after they "claim" that the health costs were too high (not a "customary" charge) and cut them down to about 25% of what was actually charged so I have to pay the "overcharge", and then they expect me to pay 20% of the 25% of what they actually did pay (if they don't find some other way to weasel out of that too). How do they know what "customary" charges should be? UnitedHealthcare owns the corporation that decides what "customary" charges should be. So a health insurance corporation decides what's a fair amount for health insurance corporations to pay the doctors, hospitals and clinics. And, surprise, surprise, it's always much lower than what you were really charged! Who would have figured, that would happen when the foxes guard the henhouse?

From the stats presented, women, not people of color, are the most highly discriminated against in terms of academy representation.  The highest paid actress in Hollywood also makes considerably less than male actors of color who are not at the top of the charts.  Why is the outrage over discrimination solely seen through a racial lens?
all said in one breath!
I agree, Stu, the press analysis is insane. 6% of the population voted in Iowa. The entire exercise was and is irrelevant. Reality, reason, please??

What, no mention of Rafael's people sending out the word that Doctor Carson was exiting the race without bothering to verify that that was actually happening?  It's hard to imagine that the good doctor's supporters would  believe he was actually suspending his campaign on the very day that their caucus was taking place (!) but, then again, anyone who would consider voting for him in the first place would conceivably believe just about anything (like the earth being only 5000 years old).  And then, of course, it was Donald Trump who leaped to the Doctor's defense (?) by intimating that Rafael's dirty deed was really all about him, because, after all, any votes withheld from Carson would ultimately be withheld from him (if not from Bush, Kasich, Krispiecreme, et al).  And, somehow or other, it's Marco Rubio, who neither won nor placed, who is determined by the press to have come away with the hearts and minds of Iowans on this day.  You can't make this stuff up.  Not even in America.

If Mephistopheles offered me $300k to make a speech, I would take it. You want to spend your money and hope it will get you a more friendly candidate, than one of the others.
As the saying in a poker game goes, you put your money in the pot, and take your chances.

Now just consider which candidate would be most susceptible to anti Socialist propaganda in the south, northern plains, and those cowboy states like Nevada, Arizona, Utah, Kansas?

.
@ David Underwood: excellent point. If the parties to the contract wanted the speech to be public, they would have brought in C-SPAN.

@ Sekhar Sundaram: Citing a piece in WaPo doesn't go far with me. Why, Michael Schmidt said in the New York Times that 2 Inspectors-General referred matters to the FBI with the recommendation that a criminal investigation be conducted, targeting Hillary Clinton's grave misdeeds. Boy, were there some Corrections printed about that one! Fortunately, NYT has a Public Editor, who wrote thoroughly about this disastrous journalism.

WaPo cut their ombudsman. Too costly. So don't tell us about an article; get the contract.
Quit playing into Republican hands.  Hillary may not be pure, but she sure is better than the alternative!
Susan H -- She is not better than the alternative. Bernie is better, and would win by a bigger margin to better purpose in reforming our politics, reforms desperately needed.

"Clinton is never going to say she’s sorry, release transcripts or announce that she’s decided to clear everything up by donating $675,000 to charity. It is what it is, and you’re going to have to take it or leave it."

Yes. And a vast chorus tells us that we just have to take it, to save the Supreme Court. As if she could be trusted on the Supreme Court either, or anything.

Why can't some decent investigative reporter find out what she said that she dare not let us know?

Is she hiding her own Mitt Romney 47% moment?

What could she say to those bankers that has her in full hide-the-ball mode? That must be what she DID say.
Really tasty! Best to use fresh corn...which in the middle of winter I could not find. But my non-vegetarian husband really enjoyed them anyways!

"...Are we talking about information that was classified after it was posted (ex post facto) or information that was classified but should not have been?"

Actually neither of these. The information, or at least some of it, was "born" classified but was never marked, or worse, the markings were stripped off and thensent to her private server.

The Secretary of State is one of the highest cabinet positions there is - 4th in line to the presidency. The Secretary's position puts her in touch with foreign officials of very high stature. Virtually all communication with foreign officials is deemed "classified" and should be stored within our highly secure gov't system. Why Ms Clinton would choose to totally ignore the sanctity of her position, flaunt the trust of the office, and be so negligent of her responsibilities is simply beyond comprehension. Is she incompetent? Too arrogant? Too... what? I really thought she was more intelligent.
Moon never played for the Redskins. You're thinking of Doug Williams.

What in the world?  All this, and no mention of his final heroic actions for the Washington Redskins, and Superbowl history?   I never saw, and have never seen since, anyone who threw a ball like Warren.  Flat down the field, 80 yards away, into the hands of his targets.   Quite, unassuming, responsible leader.  I never got to say it, but congratulations Warren, and thanks for the memories.

The college coach who took a chance on Warren Moon was the University of Washington's Don James.
"He told me that I was his guy," Moon has said..."that I was the best player he had at that position, and he was going to continue to stay with me and he just wanted to make sure that I knew that."
James, then the Huskies' new coach was only winning half of his games. His job was at stake. But he backed Moon up when sometimes all you could hear at the games was a roll of boos coming off the alumni stands.
It all paid off when James, Moon and the Huskies won the conference and the Rose Bowl. From then on, James won 75% of his games, around a dozen bowls and even the national championship in 1991.
Among the coaches James tutored were Nick Saban of Alabama and Gary Pinkel of Missouri.
James was the kind of coach who made everybody around him better. Who knows what would have happened to Warren Moon without him?
Those of us who lived part of this story think Don James is worth remembering for the example he set.

Not sure I agree. When you grow up wanting to be a QB, and at every turn, you're told to look @ a different position - you're bound to do it. At some point, the love of the game and to be on the field exceeds stubbornness.
You also needed a few things: that same stubbornness, and a program/coach who was desperately in need to win. Once upon a time, southern schools refused to play black colleges/HBCUs - like Eddie Robinson's Grambling - for fear of losing, or @ worst - get embarrassed. The all white schools had left black collegiate players few options, one of which was to all head to the black colleges/HBCUs, resulting in immense talent all on a few teams.
When traditionally white school started to open doors, that changed. But the old school owners and attitudes, are the ones to blame. If you recall, The Panthers owner once asked Cam to keep a clean cut look, if he drafted him. Imagine that...
Nice to read an informed comment. I couldn't help but note your reference to the clean cut look.  That is pervasive in the NBA, which is hardly anti-black.

Large numbers of NFL quarterbacks played high school in the South, where white quarterbacks dominate and blacks play the more athletic positions.  The fact that high school football in the South clings to stereotypes and that Texas, in particular, is a breeding ground for quarterbacks (as is California) is a big reason that blacks continue to be underrepresented among QB's.  The problem is mostly bottom up.  The NFL is only partly to blame.
If that is what you took from this article, you are the reason why the NFL was/is able to persist in its biased ways and flourish.

Moon doesn't say anything bad about his time in Edmonton - the complaint  of the article is that that over and over again, he was denied opportunities because of his race, despite his talent and accomplishments. It is only to Canada's credit that it offered opportunities where the U.S. failed, but the U.S. failures are an important story in a country with an ongoing legacy of racism.
This is a carefully crafted snarky comment. Too bad you cannot appreciate Moon for his skills and determination, without the need to undermine both by this comment.

It is unfortunate that Warren Moon came to Canada and that for him these were lost years. Such a terrible, terrible place. The plantation of the North.

It's amazing that he survived.

To my shame, I found myself watching a football game all those years ago, here in Canada, appreciating Mr. Moon's talent. Little did I know how angry he was to come to Canada, forced to make money playing a game.

Subsequently, while playing in the NFL, he signed the biggest contract that any player (black or white) had ever signed, up to that time. I try to imagine the disappointment he must have felt at that moment.

Good to see that the NY Times has used its valuable space to bring this poignant story to the attention of its readers.

Medigap plans have little to do with what is discussed in this article and discussing them here would probably only confuse people. I suggest that before you turn 65 you do some serious research.

However, I will say that both Medicare and some Medigap plans also have deductibles. Medicare Part B -- the part that covers doctor expenses -- has an annual deductible of a couple hundred dollars (Part A -- the hospital part of Medicare, has much higher deductibles). Once that Part B deductible is met, Medicare pays 80% of covered expenses. One of the things "Medigap" plans typically cover is that 20% that one has to pay out of pocket. However, the Medigap plan I have -- the high deductible version of Medigap Plan F -- only kicks in once I have paid more than $2,000 out of pocket under Medicare. In return I get a much lower premium than I would pay for an unrestricted Plan F. For my first 3 years of coverage under this plan my premium remain unchanged. This year it dropped by $6 a month, i assume because NY is a community-rated state and lower claims experience under this type of plan called for lower premiums.

I'm surprised this article never mentions the type of insurance available to older folks to fill in Medicare gaps and donut-holes. As I'm not there, I'm not keen on the details but I've seen them advertised as not only supplements to items that program dosent cover but also to reduce out of pocket payments for other reasons incl higher deductibles. they seem analogous to HSAs etc mentioned in the article. someone with experience with this type of coverage should fill us all in on details.

We all revere and lionize Jackie Robinson, as we should. But Jackie, I think, dealt with similar issues that Mr. Moon dealt with, times 10. What a player he would have been had he not been carrying all the weight he was carrying! I think Mr. Moon understands the shoulders he stood on during his own career, and great as he was, how much greater would be have been without this added weight. And what a shame that something as stupid as the American legacy of racism keeps good men and women from being all they can be, even still! Kudos to Mr. Moon for telling his story and keeping up the struggle.

Someone could say that racism is as American as apple pie or racism.

Go, QB Newton.

I lived in Edmonton during Warren Moon's years there, (and many more). Everyone knew he was 'our' quarterback because of the NFL's racism, and we were happy for him, and sad for ourselves, when he was able to go to  Houston.  The CFL worked out well for Moon, as did the Oiler's desperation.  And he also had a line of chocolate chip cookies that were well received. Still well remembered and could probably come back and be elected mayor in a landslide.

Even if they know you're a successful football player - look at the hate Cam Newton is going through as we speak. It's jaw dropping, but eye opening at the same time - serving as a reminder of the road that remains.
RG III has the same problem. That's why so many Black Redskins fans root for and support him.

Warren, I was glad you played quarterback for the Seahawks and are now our announcer.  Racism is a part of recent NFL history -- and present.  I wonder what it must be like to be a black football player.  You are a hero to the fans -- as a football player -- but just imagine the treatment by the same fans and others if they do not recognize that you are a football player.

the first black QB in professional football was Bernie custis from the university of Syracuse. he played for the Hamilton ticats in 1952. black quarterbacks were commonplace in the cfl for years. Jackie robinson broke into the international league with the montreal royals in 1946. he loved montreal for the rest of his life. he said it was the first time he was chased by whites with love on their minds instead of murder or hate....

"That was one issue State Department officials raised. But just one of many. The State Department Inspector General’s report paints a much more troubling picture of an embassy in disarray under Gration’s leadership. In the words of the auditors, Gration "has lost the respect and confidence of the staff to lead the mission." Gration ranked at or near the absolute bottom among other ambassadors assessed by the department.

His use of email was an issue, but according to an ambassador with much experience, it was a relatively minor one."
http://www.politifact.com/punditfact/statements/2015/mar/11/david-shuste...
At least someone willing to mention a source, I do not claim to be one, but Judicial Watch? I've have read some of their stuff. They think Scalia is the epitome of a SOTUS member.

IG report: " According to 12 FAM 544.3 and 11
State 73417 (from the Assistant Secretary for Diplomatic Security to the Ambassador), it is the
Department’s general policy that normal day-to-day operations be conducted on an authorized
information system, which has the proper level of security controls. The use of unauthorized
information systems increases the risk for data loss, phishing, and spoofing of email accounts, as
well as inadequate protections for personally identifiable information. The use of unauthorized
information systems can also result in the loss of official public records as these systems do not
have approved record preservation or backup functions. Conducting official business on non-Department
automated information systems must be limited to only maintaining communications " https://oig.state.gov/system/files/196460.pdf

The State Department under Secretary Clinton issued regulations prohibiting transmission of SBU, Sensitive But Unclassified information, on private email, and chief of staff Cheryl Mills used that regulation, among other matters, to fire the Ambassador to Kenya Scott Gration, according to the Inspector General's report.   Cheryl Mills and Huma Abedin need to release their emails under FOIA, and testify if they were ordered to commit a crime, as also the administrators who set up not only a server outside the department, but an insecure email computer in either Clinton's or Mills's office (according to Judicial Watch today).

Utter and complete nonsense? I think not. It's easier to hide a needle in a haystack than in a pin cushion where the seamstress would look. Additionally, foreign spies probably do not have the capability to scour all the billions of emails both in the government and everywhere else.

Not Mark...
Prove it! Prove it! I want to see sold evidence.
Post factum!

Which law(s) did she break?

Be specific.

The e-mails received and contained by Secretary Clinton's statutorily illegal server were classified at the time they were sent and received. Nothing ex post facto here.

The statutes are absolutely clear, and they apply regardless of intent.

If I conducted the same actions she did, I would be stripped of my security clearance, fired, fined, and jailed. Period.

She blatantly broke the law, and expected to be exonerated because, after all, she's a Clinton.

Try as you may, you can't make excuses for her criminal behavior.
I disagree.   The article proves beyond a shadow of a doubt why Hillary Clinton should never have set up a totally private, unsecured system to conduct the business of Secretary of State.

NO - she was trained so that she knew what was classified info..she just decided to send it in the clear.

she was an OCA - Original Classification Authority..she has no excuse.

http://www.cdse.edu/documents/cdse/oca-desktop-reference.pdf

I pity the people at the FBI who have to understand the apparently byzantine workings of the classification system and then figure out what was classified at the time of the email and whether it remains so.

Extract an apology from Hillary and a promise never to use email again if she's elected. Can we just get this over with, please?

I agree that the media are trying to control the election.  But I feel like the goal is the opposite.  It appears that Hillary is being massacred from all sides, but the media aren't focusing any serious reporting on any of the other candidates.  They haven't done a single investigative story on Ted Cruz's donors or finances or emails.  Not to mention how they're letting Donald Trump skate on EVERY issue.  Journalism is truly dead if this is the best they can do.

Given the evident ability of the Chinese to hack US government computers and help themselves to the personnel files of intelligence operatives, etc., Hillary's use of a private server may not have been so dumb after all.

And Stae Dept., not Dept. of Def. e-mails discuss their capabilities down to the nuts and bolts, i.e., to the precise capabilities of these weapons? Someone does not understand the difference between military intelligence, and diplomatic intelligence, and apparently, that includes ME.
Where I see S.D. emails revealing truly damaging information, is in discussions about how to go about 'secret discussions' with opposition groups, especially if such groups are within supposed allied countries. (e.g., NSA tapping Angela Merkel — Oops — that wasn't exposed because of HRC's private server). Any discussion of a strategy about future negotiations with any other country would be part of what, in the case of the S.D. would want classified. I'm probably misstaken, but I would not expect the CIA to inform the S.D. is any diplomats are aslo CIA handlers, never mind who the actual agents are?

It no secret that the United States deploys spy satellites, fighter aircraft , air defense systems, battle tanks, warships and special forces, but many aspects of their capabilities and operations are rightfully classified secret. The same is true of drones.
